Examples of Series Solutions

Let us present an example of the method of power series near an ordinary point.

Example. Find solutions as power series in xxx of the differential equation

y′′+xy=0.y''+xy=0.y′′+xy=0.

Solution.

First, we note that x=0x=0x=0 is an ordinary point - xxx is clearly analytic here. As such, the usual power series solution

y=∑n=0∞cn(x)ny=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n(x)^ny=n=0∑∞​cn​(x)n

will work in this case. Substituting into the equation yields

y′=∑n=1∞ncn(x)n−1y'=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} nc_n(x)^{n-1}y′=n=1∑∞​ncn​(x)n−1

(note that the range of the sum has gone from n=0n=0n=0 to n=1n=1n=1, as the derivative of the first term in yyy, a constant, is zero). And thus:

y′′=∑n=2∞n(n−1)cn(x)n−2y'' = \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} n(n-1)c_n(x)^{n-2}y′′=n=2∑∞​n(n−1)cn​(x)n−2

Substituting into the equation yields

∑n=2∞n(n−1)cn(x)n−2+∑n=0∞cn(x)n+1=0.\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} n(n-1)c_n(x)^{n-2}+ \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n(x)^{n+1} = 0.n=2∑∞​n(n−1)cn​(x)n−2+n=0∑∞​cn​(x)n+1=0.

We want to shift the ranges of the two sums so that they have the same range and can be merged into a single sum. Inspection gives the first sum as

∑n=0∞(n+2)(n+1)cn+2xn\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (n+2)(n+1)c_{n+2}x^nn=0∑∞​(n+2)(n+1)cn+2​xn

and thus the left-hand side of the DE as

2c2+∑n=1∞((n+2)(n+1)cn+2+cn−1)xn=02c_2 + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}((n+2)(n+1)c_{n+2}+c_{n-1})x^n = 02c2​+n=1∑∞​((n+2)(n+1)cn+2​+cn−1​)xn=0

It is important to note here that if a power series is zero, then all of its terms must be zero. Thus we can write:

{2c2=0  ⟺  c2=0(n+2)(n+1)cn+2+cn−1=0  ⟺  cn+2=−cn−1(n+1)(n+2), n≥1\begin{cases} 2c_2=0 \iff c_2 = 0 \\ (n+2)(n+1)c_{n+2}+c_{n-1} = 0 \iff c_{n+2}=-\frac{c_{n-1}}{(n+1)(n+2)},\ n\geq 1 \end{cases}{2c2​=0⟺c2​=0(n+2)(n+1)cn+2​+cn−1​=0⟺cn+2​=−(n+1)(n+2)cn−1​​, n≥1​

where two independent solutions arise from the values of c1c_1c1​ and c2c_2c2​.

Let's now consider an example of solutions near a regular singular point.

Example. Consider the differential equation

4xy′′+2(1−x)y′−y=0.4xy''+2(1-x)y'-y=0.4xy′′+2(1−x)y′−y=0.

Find solutions as power series in xxx.

Solution.

First, we convert the above equation to a form with coefficient of y′′y''y′′ equal to 1:

y′′+(1−x)2xy′−14xy=0y''+\frac{(1-x)}{2x}y'-\frac{1}{4x}y = 0y′′+2x(1−x)​y′−4x1​y=0

x=0x=0x=0 is a regular singular point (as the power of xxx in the denominators of 1−x2x\frac{1-x}{2x}2x1−x​ does not exceed 1, and in 14x\frac{1}{4x}4x1​, it does not exceed 2). We know from Fuch's Theorem that there exists a solution of the form

y=∑n=0∞cnxn+σy=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}c_n x^{n+\sigma}y=n=0∑∞​cn​xn+σ

with corresponding derivatives

y′=∑n=0∞cn(n+σ)xn+σ−1, y′′=∑n=0∞cn(n+σ)(n+σ−1)xn+σ−2y'=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}c_n(n+\sigma) x^{n+\sigma-1}, \ y'' =\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}c_n(n+\sigma)(n+\sigma -1)x^{n+\sigma-2}y′=n=0∑∞​cn​(n+σ)xn+σ−1, y′′=n=0∑∞​cn​(n+σ)(n+σ−1)xn+σ−2

Substituting into the equation gives:

∑n=0∞[4cn(n+σ)(n+σ−1)+2cn(n+σ)]xn+σ−1−∑n=0∞[2cn(n+σ)+1]xn+σ=0\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}[4c_n(n+\sigma)(n+\sigma-1)+2c_n(n+\sigma)]x^{n+\sigma-1} - \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}[2c_n(n+\sigma)+1]x^{n+\sigma} = 0n=0∑∞​[4cn​(n+σ)(n+σ−1)+2cn​(n+σ)]xn+σ−1−n=0∑∞​[2cn​(n+σ)+1]xn+σ=0

and thus

{[4c0(σ)(σ−1)+2c0(σ)]xσ−1=0∑n=0∞[2cn+1(n+σ)(2(n+σ+1)+1)−2cn(n+σ)−cn]xn+σ=0\begin{cases} [4c_0(\sigma)(\sigma-1)+2c_0(\sigma)]x^{\sigma}-1=0 \\ \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}[2c_{n+1}(n+\sigma)(2(n+\sigma+1)+1)-2c_n(n+\sigma)-c_n]x^{n+\sigma} = 0 \end{cases}{[4c0​(σ)(σ−1)+2c0​(σ)]xσ−1=0∑n=0∞​[2cn+1​(n+σ)(2(n+σ+1)+1)−2cn​(n+σ)−cn​]xn+σ=0​

The first term, involving only σ\sigmaσ, is known as the indicial equation (determines the value of the index):

4c0(σ)(σ−1)+2c0(σ)=0  ⟺  σ(σ−1)+σ2=0, σ=0, 124c_0(\sigma)(\sigma-1)+2c_0(\sigma) = 0 \iff \sigma(\sigma-1)+\frac{\sigma}{2}=0,\ \sigma=0,\ \frac{1}{2}4c0​(σ)(σ−1)+2c0​(σ)=0⟺σ(σ−1)+2σ​=0, σ=0, 21​

From the second term we obtain the recurrence relation

2cn+1(n+σ)(2(n+σ+1)+1)−2cn(n+σ)−cn=02c_{n+1}(n+\sigma)(2(n+\sigma+1)+1)-2c_n(n+\sigma)-c_n=02cn+1​(n+σ)(2(n+σ+1)+1)−2cn​(n+σ)−cn​=0

or equivalently

cn+1=1+2(n+σ)2(n+σ)(2(n+σ+1)+1)cnc_{n+1}=\frac{1+2(n+\sigma)}{2(n+\sigma)(2(n+\sigma+1)+1)}c_ncn+1​=2(n+σ)(2(n+σ+1)+1)1+2(n+σ)​cn​

where σ=0, 12\sigma = 0,\ \frac{1}{2}σ=0, 21​ can be plugged in to obtain two independent solutions.
